Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the lack of effort to get American experts into China by stating that "there was no effort" when in fact, there were efforts made by Health and Human Services officials to send American experts to China.
Understate: The claim may understate the efforts made by the Trump administration to offer assistance to China and President Xi. Trump is quoted as saying, "We have offered China and President Xi any help that is necessary."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to substantiate the statement that "we had one person in-country (and Trump) pulled him out of the country." The provided evidence does not explicitly mention Trump pulling out a person from China.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Trump's trade deal with China influenced his decision not to put pressure on Xi to allow American experts into China. This is a problematic assumption as it does not provide concrete evidence to support this claim.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation could be that China initially resisted American and World Health Organization teams but eventually allowed a WHO team, including some Americans, to enter the country. This alternative explanation challenges the claim that there was no effort to get American experts into China.
